docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, was not supposed to be like this. He was supposed to be a creature of the far-right fringe of his party, at least according to the opponent he defeated in the Illinois Republican primary last year. He was supposed to be a lock-step soldier in the conservative brigade, at least according to his Democratic adversary in the general election, former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun.

headline.main: Freshman Senator Bucks His Billing, and the G.O.P.

docs.snippet: Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, was not supposed to be like this.    He was supposed to be a creature of the far-right fringe of his party, at least according to the opponent he defeated in the Illinois Republican primary last...

docs.lead_paragraph: ADOLESCENT girls feel an overwhelming pressure to be smart, beautiful, popular and mature. That pressure, from parents, peers, and the media, can lead to depression, eating disorders, self-mutilation and sexual experiences that happen too soon. So says 18-year-old Sara Shandler, a student at Wesleyan University and the author of ''Ophelia Speaks'' (HarperCollins, 1999), a book of essays by teen-age girls ages 12 to 18 on topics ranging from eating disorders and body image to teen pregnancy and relationships with parents. She said she hopes girls will take away the message that they are not alone and their experiences aren't unique.

headline.main: Life Through the Eyes of Teen-Age Girls

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Sara Shandler, 18, student at Wesleyan University who has written book Ophelia Speaks, essays by teenage girls ages 12 to 18 on variety of life issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE plains start at the intersection of Reeves and Roanoke Avenues, just beyond downtown Riverhead. Grazing in a field littered with cobs of corn, 32 buffalo are home on Ed Tuccio's range. Yes, buffalo. Those shaggy, hunchbacked bison, immortalized on the nickel, whose hooves once thundered across the Wild West. Hunted by the Indians, slaughtered by the white man, buffalo are increasing in number on Mr. Tuccio's 240-acre North Quarter farm, the only bison ranch on Long Island. There are almost 1,000 buffalo in New York State.

headline.main: In Riverhead, Where the Buffalo Roam

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column: Dee Muma and Ed Tuccio are breeding herd of 32 buffalo in Riverhead, only bison ranch on Long Island; Sports Plus, family entertainment center in Lake Grove, Long Island, now has BattleTech, first vitrual attraction on Long Island; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON the third day of the July heat wave, I couldn't stand it any longer. Dragging myself out from under the air-conditioner, I drove east to a place that had previously been just a legend to me: the Splish Splash Water Park, just outside Riverhead. All three million people on Long Island, and most of the population of Brooklyn and Queens, had apparently had the same brilliant idea. The overflow parking lot was already filling up at 9:30 A.M., and it felt like 100 degrees already. I joined a growing crowd waiting in line for the tram that would carry us to the main entrance. As we stood there, slowly dehydrating in the sun, an overhead loudspeaker delivered the first of many lists of warnings: no metal parts on bathing attire; no food or beverages; no hot dogging; no running; no Jet Skis.

headline.main: Wet 'n' Mild at a Water Park

docs.abstract: David Bouchier essay on recent trip to overcrowded Splish Splash Water Park near Riverhead, Long Island, during summer heat wave; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the final hours of a sharply partisan debate over health care, the Senate killed a Democratic effort to expand the ability of patients to sue managed-care providers and, in a near party-line vote tonight, approved a Republican plan to regulate the companies that provide health insurance for most Americans. The bill, designed to grapple with the health care revolution that has shifted most Americans into managed care, passed by a vote of 53 to 47. Two Republicans, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Peter Fitzgerald of Illinois, broke ranks with their party to oppose the measure.

headline.main: SENATE APPROVES REPUBLICAN PLAN FOR HEALTH CARE

docs.abstract: US Senate kills Democratic effort to expand ability of patients to sue managed-care providers and, in near party-line vote, approves Republican plan to regulate companies that provide health insurance for most Americans; bill, designed to grapple with health care revolution that has shifted most Americans into managed care, passes by vote of 53 to 47; two Republicans, John H Chafee of Rhode Island and Peter Fitzgerald of Illinois, break ranks with their party to oppose measure; legislation would provide $13 billion in new tax breaks for health care and give array of rights to consumers, mostly significantly creating an appeal process for 124 million Americans in employer-sponsored health plans; extent of other new protections--including consumer information, right to hospital stay after a mastectomy if recommended by a doctor, access to emergency room outside of managed-care network--would vary according to person's insurance coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an advancement that promises to significantly reduce the incidence of AIDS in children in developing countries, American and Ugandan scientists have found a simple new way to prevent mother-to-child transmission of the AIDS virus that also is less costly and markedly more effective than the standard therapy in the third world. The more practical therapy comes from substituting one marketed drug, nevirapine, for the standard drug, AZT. The cost for the two doses of nevirapine was $4, compared with $268 for the AZT regimen now used in developing countries and $815 for the much longer and more complicated course used in the United States and other developed countries, Federal health officials said in releasing the findings yesterday.

headline.main: NEW MEANS FOUND FOR REDUCING H.I.V. PASSED TO CHILD

docs.abstract: American and Ugandan scientists report finding simple new way to prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS virus that is also less costly and markedly more effective than standard therapy used in Third World; new method involves substitution of drug, nevirapine, for AZT; cost for two doses of nevirapine is $4, compared with $268 for AZT regimen used in developing countries and $815 for much longer and more complicated course used in US and other developed countries; new treatment calls for mother and infant to take nevirapine just once, with mother taking pill once during labor and child ingesting it as syrup once during first three days of life (M)
